messageBody:
Stephen,

I'm not sure I understand your problem ... It seems to me to be the
following : how to test a "component" model ?, i.e. how to test some
class that need a container to work (like Applets, EJBs, Avalon
Components, Servlets, etc).

There are 2 good solutions (for unit tests) :
- in-container testing. Cactus does this for J2EE APIs
or
- mock objects (www.mockobjects.com) by mocking your container (beware,
it is not the same a stubbing).

Now, it really depends if you want to write unit tests (white box) or
functional tests (black box).

-Vincent

> Hello Vincent,

> It is me, thanks for coming back. I am actually using log4j, but I
> mentioned
> system.out.writeln as a simplification.
>
> The real problem I had really is how to invoke the entire
> application/applet
> inside a test case. It is easy to write a testcase to invoke a
particular
> method in a particular class. However I cannot simply call the init()
in
> the
> JApplet implementation - I need to simulate the applet life-cycle. Of
> course
> I would have to simulate the keystrokes and mouse - I am investigating
> Jemmy
> for this purpose.
>
> The situation is not as complicated with applications, since I should
be
> able to simply call the main() with the appropriate arguments.
>
> Regards,
> Stephen
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Vincent Massol [mailto:vmassol@...]

> To: stephen.cheng@...

>
>
> Stephen,
>
> Are you the Stephen Cheng I met at Icom ?
>
> There are several solutions to your question.
>
> 1/ First it is not good to do System.out.println ! You should rather
use
> a logging toolkit. I would suggest Jakarta Commons Logging as it
> transparently let you use log4j, jdk1.4, logkit or simple logging
using
> system.out, I think. If you do this, then you can provide a mock
> implementation of the logger and assert whatever you want.
>
> 2/ Simply redirect the out stream to a memory stream and then compare
> the memory stream with the expected result.
>
> Hope it helps.
> -Vincent
